title: How to make a mummy - Len Bloch

options.label: C

title: Andy Warhol, Campbell's Soup Cans: Why is this Art?

multiple-choice.question: Why did Andy Warhol's Campbell Soup Cans series become art, while the same images used in advertising would not be considered art?

options.label: A
options.text: Because Warhol's version was more aesthetically pleasing.

options.label: B
options.text: Because Warhol's version was more technically skilled.

options.label: C
options.text: Because Warhol's version was presented in a museum, changing the viewer's perspective.

options.label: D
options.text: Because Warhol's version was more expensive to produce.

multiple-choice.question: What was one of the key ideas behind Warhol's Campbell Soup Cans series?

options.label: A
options.text: To focus on the technical skill of the artist.

options.label: B
options.text: To create a new and unique visual language.

options.label: C
options.text: To explore the relationship between art and mass production.

options.label: D
options.text: To create a series of beautiful and intricate paintings.

options.label: A
options.text: He taught Warhol how to create beautiful and intricate paintings.

options.label: B
options.text: He showed Warhol how to use a printer to create art.

options.label: C
options.text: He gave Warhol permission to focus on the idea rather than the technical skill.

options.label: D
options.text: He inspired Warhol to create a series of sculptures.

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of Warhol's decision to use a printer to create the Campbell Soup Cans?

options.label: A
options.text: It showed that he was a master of traditional art techniques.

options.label: B
options.text: It highlighted the importance of manual labor in art.

options.label: C
options.text: It reflected the way that we manufacture and construct our world.

options.label: D
options.text: It was a way for Warhol to prove that he was a skilled artist.

multiple-choice.question: Why did Warhol's work feel radical and shocking in 1962, but may seem less unique today?

options.label: A
options.text: Because Warhol's work was more beautiful and intricate than other art of the time.

options.label: B
options.text: Because Warhol's work was more technically skilled than other art of the time.

options.label: C
options.text: Because Warhol's work challenged the traditional notions of what art should be.

options.label: D
options.text: Because Warhol's work was more expensive to produce than other art of the time.

title: Can you solve the famously difficult green-eyed logic puzzle? - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: Imagine an island with 100 prisoners, all of whom have green eyes but don't know their own eye color. They're not allowed to communicate with each other, but they see each other during the daily head count. What can be said to help the prisoners escape without incurring the dictator's wrath?

options.label: A
options.text: "I have green eyes."

options.label: B
options.text: "At least one of you has green eyes."

options.label: C
options.text: "No one has green eyes."

options.label: D
options.text: "Everyone has blue eyes."

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the concept that allows the prisoners to escape?

options.label: A
options.text: The concept of probability

options.label: B
options.text: The concept of common knowledge

options.label: C
options.text: The concept of induction

options.label: D
options.text: The concept of deduction

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They were waiting for each other to confirm the presence of green-eyed people.

options.label: D
options.text: They were waiting for the island to be evacuated.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: 100 prisoners

options.label: C
options.text: 98 prisoners

options.label: D
options.text: 50 prisoners

options.label: A
options.text: Each prisoner must see at least one green-eyed person to escape.

options.label: B
options.text: Each prisoner must know that everyone else is keeping track of the green-eyed people they can see.

options.label: C
options.text: Each prisoner must be able to communicate with each other.

options.label: D
options.text: Each prisoner must have a simple arithmetic calculation.

options.text: He killed his father and married his mother, and then took his own life.

options.text: He stabbed his eyes repeatedly after finding his mother dead.

multiple-choice.question: Who won the competition and took first prize, much to the surprise of the audience?

options.label: A
options.text: Aeschylus

options.label: B
options.text: Sophocles

options.label: C
options.text: Philocles

options.label: D
options.text: Thespis

title: Will future spacecraft fit in our pockets? - Dhonam Pemba

multiple-choice.question: What is one potential benefit of sending microspacecraft into the galaxy?

options.label: A
options.text: They could carry more fuel than a space shuttle mission.

options.label: B
options.text: They could deploy thousands of them for the cost of a single space shuttle mission.

options.label: C
options.text: They could explore distant stars and planets by carrying sophisticated electronic sensors.

options.label: D
options.text: They could only be used for scientific instruments.

multiple-choice.question: What is one way that microspacecraft can propel themselves?

options.label: A
options.text: They use a large engine to generate momentum.

options.label: B
options.text: They harness surface tension and capillary action to power spacecraft.

options.label: C
options.text: They use a combination of Newtonian mechanics and electromagnetism.

options.label: D
options.text: They are propelled by a type of ion thruster.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the type of ion thruster being developed at NASA's jet propulsion laboratory?

options.label: A
options.text: Microfluidic electrospray propulsion

options.label: B
options.text: Microionic propulsion

options.label: C
options.text: Microelectrostatic propulsion

options.label: D
options.text: Microelectromagnetic propulsion

multiple-choice.question: What is one characteristic of microspacecraft that makes them suitable for long deep-space missions?

options.label: A
options.text: They have a large engine that generates a lot of thrust.

options.label: B
options.text: They have a small exhaust stream that is far more fuel efficient.

options.label: C
options.text: They have a large amount of fuel that allows them to travel long distances.

options.label: D
options.text: They have a high speed that allows them to travel quickly through space.

multiple-choice.question: What is one potential outcome of the development of microspacecraft with micropropulsion systems?

options.label: A
options.text: Thousands of microspacecraft will be launched in the next ten years to gather data on the Earth's atmosphere.

options.label: B
options.text: Microspacecraft will only be used for short-distance missions.

options.label: C
options.text: Microspacecraft will be able to break free of Earth's orbit and gather data on distant stars and planets.

options.label: D
options.text: Microspacecraft will be too expensive to develop and launch.

title: How batteries work - Adam Jacobson

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why batteries diminish daily and eventually die?

options.label: A
options.text: The metal in the battery is constantly being oxidized and reduced.

options.label: B
options.text: The chemical solution inside the battery is slowly being depleted.

options.label: C
options.text: The electrons in the battery are being used up and cannot be replenished.

options.label: D
options.text: The battery is being overcharged and overheated.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of Luigi Galvani's experiment with a frog's leg and a metal instrument?

options.label: A
options.text: The frog's leg twitched due to the electricity stored in the frog's body.

options.label: B
options.text: The frog's leg twitched due to the metal instrument, but Galvani believed it was the frog's body that was responsible.

options.label: C
options.text: The frog's leg did not twitch at all.

options.label: D
options.text: The frog's leg twitched due to the chemical solution used in the experiment.

multiple-choice.question: What is the principle behind a battery's ability to store charge and provide power?

options.label: A
options.text: Oxidation and reduction occur in the metal itself, producing electricity.

options.label: B
options.text: Oxidation and reduction occur in the chemical solution, producing electricity.

options.label: C
options.text: Oxidation and reduction occur between two substances, producing a flow of electrons.

options.label: D
options.text: Oxidation and reduction do not occur at all, and the battery stores electricity through a different mechanism.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary limitation of rechargeable batteries?

options.label: A
options.text: They are too heavy and bulky.

options.label: B
options.text: They are too expensive to manufacture.

options.label: C
options.text: They can only be recharged a limited number of times before they die.

options.label: D
options.text: They are too sensitive to temperature and humidity.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary advantage of using a charger to recharge a battery?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows the battery to be recharged faster.

options.label: B
options.text: It allows the battery to be recharged more efficiently.

options.label: C
options.text: It reverses the oxidation-reduction process, regenerating the metal and making more electrons available.

options.label: D
options.text: It does not affect the battery's lifespan.

options.text: A group of friends discussing a birthday party

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C

title: Debunking the myths of OCD - Natascha M. Santos

multiple-choice.question: What is a common misconception about Obsessive Compulsive Disorder (OCD)?

options.label: A
options.text: That it is a rare condition that affects only a few people.

options.label: B
options.text: That OCD is a serious psychiatric condition that is frequently misunderstood by society and mental health professionals alike.

options.label: C
options.text: That repetitive or ritualistic behaviors are synonymous with OCD.

options.label: D
options.text: That OCD only affects people who are messy and disorganized.

multiple-choice.question: What are two aspects of Obsessive Compulsive Disorder (OCD)?

options.label: A
options.text: Intrusive thoughts and compulsive behaviors.

options.label: B
options.text: Obsessive tendencies and compulsive behaviors.

options.label: C
options.text: Anxiety and depression.

options.label: D
options.text: Fear and aggression.

multiple-choice.question: What is one example of a compulsive behavior that is often associated with OCD?

options.label: A
options.text: Excessive hand washing.

options.label: B
options.text: Checking things repeatedly.

options.label: C
options.text: Both A and B.

options.label: D
options.text: Neither A nor B.

multiple-choice.question: What is a neurotransmitter that is associated with low levels in people with OCD?

options.label: A
options.text: Dopamine.

options.label: B
options.text: Serotonin.

options.label: C
options.text: Endorphins.

options.label: D
options.text: GABA.

multiple-choice.question: What is one effective treatment for OCD that involves gradually desensitizing patients to their anxieties?

options.label: A
options.text: Medications.

options.label: B
options.text: Behavioral therapy.

options.label: C
options.text: Electroconvulsive therapy.

options.label: D
options.text: Surgery.

title: The complex geometry of Islamic design - Eric Broug

multiple-choice.question: In Islamic culture, geometry is a significant element in which of the following structures?

options.label: A
options.text: Mosques, madrasas, and private homes only

options.label: B
options.text: Mosques, madrasas, palaces, and private homes

options.label: C
options.text: Mosques and palaces only

options.label: D
options.text: Madrasas and private homes only

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary tool used by craftsmen in Islamic geometric design?

options.label: A
options.text: A pencil and paper

options.label: B
options.text: A compass and a ruler

options.label: C
options.text: A computer and software

options.label: D
options.text: A paintbrush and paint

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the number of rays on a starburst in Islamic geometric design?

options.label: A
options.text: It determines the color of the pattern

options.label: B
options.text: It determines the shape of the pattern

options.label: C
options.text: It determines the category of the pattern (fourfold, fivefold, or sixfold)

options.label: D
options.text: It determines the size of the pattern

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of an underlying grid in Islamic geometric design?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a random pattern

options.label: B
options.text: To facilitate the invention of new patterns

options.label: C
options.text: To keep the pattern accurate and determine the scale of the composition

options.label: D
options.text: To add color to the pattern

multiple-choice.question: What is the process called when creating a repeating pattern by repeating a single tile?

options.label: A
options.text: Tessellation

options.label: B
options.text: Geometric design

options.label: C
options.text: Pattern creation

options.label: D
options.text: Shape formation

title: Sunlight is way older than you think - Sten Odenwald

multiple-choice.question: How long does it take for a photon to travel from the Sun's core to its surface?

options.label: A
options.text: A few seconds or a minute at most

options.label: B
options.text: Many thousands of years

options.label: C
options.text: 400 billion years

options.label: D
options.text: 170,000 years

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the formula used to calculate the distance a photon travels from the center of the Sun after each collision?

options.label: A
options.text: Random walk equation

options.label: B
options.text: Distance equals step size times the square root of the number of steps

options.label: C
options.text: Solar interior model

options.label: D
options.text: Photon-energy relationship

multiple-choice.question: Why does the Sun's density affect the travel time of a photon?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it affects the number of protons the photon interacts with

options.label: B
options.text: Because it affects the energy of the photon

options.label: C
options.text: Because it affects the distance between protons

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What determines how likely a photon is to interact with a proton?

options.label: A
options.text: The energy of the photon

options.label: B
options.text: The density of the Sun

options.label: C
options.text: The distance between protons

options.label: D
options.text: The speed of the photon

multiple-choice.question: Approximately how many years ago did the photon hitting your eyes today begin its journey?

options.label: A
options.text: 400 billion years ago

options.label: B
options.text: 170,000 years ago

options.label: C
options.text: 4.6 billion years ago

options.label: D
options.text: 2 ice ages ago
